concreteImpact.budget: No new budget can be voted. The Region operates on the basis of the previous budget, rolled over through provisional twelfths. New investments are legally impossible and the real value of existing expenditure is eroded by inflation.
concreteImpact.mobility: Major infrastructure projects (Metro 3, tunnel renovations, new phases of Good Move) cannot receive political approval. STIB (Brussels transit) maintains existing services but no new development can be launched.
concreteImpact.employment: The Region cannot create new employment programmes or adapt its measures to the federal unemployment reform. Existing measures continue but without the possibility of adjustment in response to rising unemployment.
concreteImpact.housing: No new social housing programme can be launched. The Housing Fund has suspended its lending. The waiting list (62,234 households) grows each month with no possibility of a structural policy response.
concreteImpact.climate: The new phases of the Air-Climate-Energy Plan cannot be launched. Renolution energy renovation grants are limited to existing budgets. The trajectory towards the target of -40% CO2 by 2030 is falling behind due to the absence of new decisions.
concreteImpact.social: Bi-community investments by COCOM (Joint Community Commission) are frozen. CPAS (public social welfare centres) face a surge in requests without additional resources. New initiatives in mental health and homelessness policy are on hold.
concreteImpact.security: The new government plans an anti-drugs commissioner, a €10 million investment in railway stations, connecting CCTV systems and reinforcing the fire service (SIAMU). These measures must be funded through the 2026 budget.
concreteImpact.economy: The new government plans an Urban Free Zone at the Port and Forest, positioning Brussels as an AI capital, and opening Kanal museum. Implementation depends on implementing decrees and the budget.
concreteImpact.cleanliness: The new government plans a reform of Brussels Cleanliness Agency, regional brigades, underground waste containers and immediate fines. Implementation depends on the budget and coordination with municipalities.
concreteImpact.institutional: The new government plans to merge 25 structures into 4 pillars, cutting costs by 20-30%. Pillars 1 and 2 must be operational in 2026, but some mergers require special majorities in Parliament.

whyStatus.budget: Voting a new regional budget requires a fully empowered government (Special Law of 12 January 1989). Under caretaker government, Parliament can only vote provisional twelfths. No alternative authority exists for this competence. The active fallback mechanism is the rollover of the previous budget through provisional twelfths (ordinance of 20/12/2024).
whyStatus.mobility: The Metro 3 and Good Move Phase 2 projects require government decisions (approval of public procurement, multi-year budget commitments). These decisions fall outside the scope of caretaker government. Parliament has questioned the outgoing government on this matter. STIB (Brussels transit) continues its day-to-day operations but the contractual deadlines for Metro 3 have been exceeded.
whyStatus.employment: Regional employment activation measures (training plans, subsidised jobs) have regulatory deadlines that are expiring. Renewing these measures requires government decisions. Actiris continues its day-to-day operations but cannot adapt its programmes to the federal unemployment reform.
whyStatus.housing: The creation of social housing and the allocation of credits to the Housing Fund require new budget commitments, which are impossible under caretaker government. The SLRB (Brussels social housing agency) continues managing the existing stock but cannot launch any new construction. The waiting list exceeds 62,000 households, a record threshold.
whyStatus.climate: The adoption of the new phases of the Air-Climate-Energy Plan (PACE) requires government approval. The deadlines set by the 2030 target have been formally exceeded without a structural decision. Brussels Environment continues its existing programmes but without a new budget for expanded Renolution grants.
whyStatus.social: Investment decisions by COCOM (Joint Community Commission, a bi-community competence) require political approval that is impossible under caretaker government. CPAS (public social welfare centres) depend on regional subsidies whose budgets cannot be increased. Iriscare operates in minimal mode. The number of counted homeless persons is rising without the possibility of a policy response.
whyStatus.security: The Security chapter of the RPD provides for an integrated regional plan: an anti-drugs commissioner, €10M for securing South and North stations, interconnection of CCTV systems and reinforcement of SIAMU (fire service). These measures require implementing decrees and budget allocations in the 2026 budget.
whyStatus.economy: The Economy chapter of the RPD provides for the creation of an Urban Free Zone (Brussels Port + Audi Forest site), positioning Brussels as an AI capital, and opening the Kanal museum under new governance. Implementation depends on implementing decrees and the 2026 budget.
whyStatus.cleanliness: The Cleanliness chapter of the RPD provides for a reform of the Brussels Cleanliness Agency (ABP), regional cleanliness brigades, underground waste containers and immediate fine collection. Implementation depends on budget allocations in the 2026 budget.
whyStatus.institutional: Chapter 4 of the RPD provides for the merger of 25 regional structures into 4 pillars, with savings of 20-30% on operating costs. Pillars 1 and 2 must be operational by 2026. Some mergers require special majorities in Parliament.

notSaid.budget: This card does not say that the current budget is inherently insufficient — it documents that the absence of a new budget prevents any adaptation to current economic realities. The correlation between caretaker government and budgetary deterioration is not presented as direct causation.
notSaid.mobility: This card does not say that the mobility projects have been cancelled — it documents that they are awaiting a political decision. The observed delay may have multiple causes, some of which predate the government crisis.
notSaid.employment: This card does not say that rising unemployment is caused by the absence of government — it documents that regional response measures are frozen while the unemployment rate evolves. Employment dynamics depend on multiple factors (economic conditions, federal reform, economic structure).
notSaid.housing: This card does not say that the housing crisis was born with the government crisis — the social housing deficit is structural and predates it. It documents that the absence of government prevents any new policy response to a deteriorating situation.
notSaid.climate: This card does not say that Brussels will miss its climate targets because of the absence of government — it documents that the decision-making mechanisms needed to reach those targets are frozen. Reaching the 2030 target depends on many factors beyond regional governance.
notSaid.social: This card does not say that social services have stopped functioning — CPAS (public social welfare centres) and Iriscare continue their core mission. It documents that new investments, capacity adjustments, and structural reforms are impossible under caretaker government.
notSaid.security: This page does not claim that the regional security plan will solve all safety challenges — it documents the quantified commitments from the RPD. Effectiveness depends on actual funding, coordination with police zones and federal cooperation.
notSaid.economy: This page does not claim that economic measures will guarantee growth — it documents the RPD commitments on attractiveness and development. Actual impact will depend on the international economic climate and effective implementation of announced measures.
notSaid.cleanliness: This page does not claim that cleanliness measures will solve the problem immediately — it documents the concrete commitments from the RPD. Effectiveness depends on deployment of resources, Region-municipality coordination and user behaviour.
notSaid.institutional: This page does not claim that institutional simplification will be straightforward — it documents the rationalisation commitments from the RPD. These reforms require complex political agreements and special majorities in Parliament.

editorial.title: Editorial Charter
editorial.intro: Brussels Governance Monitor is a civic information project. This charter defines the principles that guide our editorial work.

principles.title: Core principles
principles.neutrality: Factual neutrality: we report facts, not opinions. No political stance.
principles.sources: Mandatory sourcing: every claim is accompanied by its source (official document, press release, news article, statistical data).
principles.factOpinion: Fact/interpretation distinction: analyses are clearly identified as such and separated from raw facts.
principles.transparency: Funding transparency: the project is hosted by Advice That SRL. It is not funded by any political party or interest group.
principles.noPartisan: No partisan affiliation: no politician names appear in the cards. Content focuses on mechanisms, not individuals.
principles.rightOfReply: Right of reply: any person or institution cited may request a correction or addition via our contact address.

verification.title: Verification process
verification.description: Each card is verified through a two-step process: two independent sources, or a single recognised institutional source (Court of Auditors, parliament, regional administration). Metrics systematically indicate their confidence level.

confidence.title: Confidence levels
confidence.officialDesc: Data from a published official document (law, report, institutional statistic).
confidence.estimatedDesc: Estimate based on partial data, extrapolations, or reliable secondary sources.
confidence.unconfirmedDesc: Information not yet verifiable by a second source. Explicitly flagged.

corrections.title: Corrections and updates
corrections.description: Any reported error is corrected as soon as possible. Corrections are tracked: each card indicates its last modification date and the nature of the change. Version history is available via the public GitHub repository.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.subtitle: Understanding Brussels governance: sourced questions and answers

questions.q1: Why doesn't Brussels have a government?
questions.a1: Since the regional elections of 9 June 2024, Brussels political parties have failed to form a majority coalition in parliament. Brussels' institutional structure, which requires majorities in both linguistic groups, complicates formation. Several attempts have failed due to disagreements over coalition formulas and the distribution of competences.
questions.a2: A caretaker government can only manage day-to-day matters and continue existing commitments. It cannot launch new policies, vote a new budget, or make strategic decisions. The budget is managed through provisional twelfths: each month, one twelfth of the previous budget is rolled over.
questions.q3: What are the concrete impacts for residents?
questions.a3: Infrastructure projects are frozen (Metro 3, tunnel renovations), housing policies are suspended (Housing Fund, rental guarantee), the job market suffers from inaction (ONEM exclusions), and the regional budget loses real value due to inflation without possible adjustment.
questions.q4: Has this happened before in Belgium?
questions.a4: At the federal level, yes. Belgium held the world record for the longest period without a government: 541 days between 2010 and 2011. At the Brussels regional level, the current situation is unprecedented in both duration and complexity.
questions.a5: The Brussels political parties elected to the regional parliament. It is the President of the Brussels Parliament who steers the formation process and designates informateurs, formateurs, or facilitators (unlike at the federal level, the King plays no role in the formation of the regional government). As a last resort, new regional elections are theoretically possible but constitutionally near-impossible.
questions.a6: An emergency budget mechanism that rolls over one twelfth of the last approved budget each month. This allows salaries and current expenses to be paid but prevents any new investment and any adjustment to inflation or changing needs.
questions.a7: All our data comes from official sources (Court of Auditors, Brussels parliament, regional administrations) or reliable secondary sources (press, academic studies). Every figure is accompanied by its source and confidence level. Everything is available on the Data page.
questions.q8: Is BGM affiliated with a political party?
questions.a8: No. Brussels Governance Monitor is an independent project hosted by Advice That SRL. It is not funded or supported by any political party, trade union, or interest group. The source code is publicly available to ensure full transparency. All rights reserved.
questions.a9: You can report an error, propose a correction, or submit new sources via our GitHub repository. The source code is open and contributions are welcome. You can also subscribe to email alerts to follow the evolution of the situation.
questions.a10: There is no legal limit to the duration of caretaker government in Belgium. The situation could theoretically last until the next regional elections scheduled for 2029. In practice, citizen pressure, media attention, and European budget deadlines could accelerate negotiations.
questions.a11: Brussels is simultaneously a Region, the capital of Belgium, the seat of the EU, and a city of 19 autonomous municipalities. Six different governments exercise competences there (federal, regional, COCOM, COCOF, VGC, municipal). Forming a regional government requires a double linguistic majority (FR + NL), which complicates coalition-building. This institutional architecture, unique in the world, is the result of historical compromises between linguistic communities.

methodology.title: Our method
methodology.intro: Brussels Governance Monitor observes the concrete effects of the absence of a fully empowered government in Brussels. Its purpose is neither political nor activist, but civic: to make institutional information that is often scattered, silent, or difficult to access readable, verifiable, and contestable.

mission.title: What BGM documents
mission.known: and what is actually known at any given moment.

model.title: A simple model: Card / Event / Verification
model.cardsDesc: Describe the state of a domain (budget, mobility, social affairs...) or a sector, based on public sources.
model.eventsDesc: Document specific institutional facts (vote, decision, publication, missed deadline).
model.verificationsDesc: Documented editorial acts that confirm, refute, or suspend existing information at a given date.
model.conclusion: This model makes institutional silence visible, without speculation.

statuses.title: Statuses based on verifiable criteria
statuses.description: Each card has a procedural status:
statuses.criteria: These statuses are based on binary criteria, are reproducible by a third party, and depend on neither political opinion nor moral judgement.
statuses.prudence: Doubt never automatically leads to the most severe status.

dataSources.title: An explicit source hierarchy
dataSources.description: BGM classifies its sources by nature and robustness:
dataSources.tierADesc: Published official documents, including ordinances, Court of Auditors reports, Statbel/IBSA statistics, parliamentary minutes
dataSources.tierBDesc: Institutional communications, including Actiris, STIB, SLRB, Brussels Environment, Iriscare, Brulocalis, BISA
dataSources.tierCDesc: Reference press, including RTBF, VRT, Le Soir, De Standaard, L'Echo, La Libre, BX1, BRUZZ — used when the primary source is not available online
dataSources.tierDDesc: Analyses and studies, including Brupartners, universities, think tanks — provide context for raw data
dataSources.noSource: No information is published without an identifiable source. Links, consultation dates, and limitations are always indicated.
dataSources.allSources: View the full list of our sources

estimations.title: Strictly framed estimations
estimations.description: When BGM produces an estimation (e.g. budget adjustment, temporal comparison):
estimations.signaled: it is explicitly flagged as an estimation,
estimations.publicData: it is based on public data,
estimations.documented: its method, assumptions, and limitations are documented,
estimations.margin: a margin of uncertainty is indicated.
estimations.conclusion: An estimation is never presented as an official fact.

uncertainty.title: Uncertainty management is part of the system
uncertainty.description: BGM never forces a conclusion. When information becomes uncertain, contradictory, or unverifiable, it is:
uncertainty.conclusion: Not concluding is sometimes the most rigorous position.

limitations.title: What BGM does not do
limitations.noPersonalization: No political personalisation (no names, no parties)

transparency.title: Transparency and contestation
transparency.description: All information published by BGM is sourced, dated, and verifiable.
transparency.channel: A public contestation channel allows any citizen, journalist, or institution to:
transparency.response: Every admissible contestation receives a documented response.

selfLimitations.title: Acknowledged limitations
selfLimitations.framing: a framing centred on the impact of the absence of government,
selfLimitations.coverage: coverage limited to certain priority domains,
selfLimitations.dataDependency: a dependency on the availability of public data,
selfLimitations.conclusion: These limitations are documented, not concealed.

methodology.tagline: Brussels Governance Monitor does not tell you what to think. It shows what is verifiable, what is not, and why.

confidence.title: Our confidence levels
confidence.officialDesc: Published institutional source — data directly verifiable in the source document
confidence.estimatedDesc: BGM estimate based on partial data, with documented methodology
confidence.unconfirmedDesc: Information reported by the press only, not yet confirmed by an institutional source

independence.title: Our independence
independence.description: BGM is a project hosted by Advice That SRL, with no partisan, trade union, or media affiliation. Funding is transparent: no public subsidies, no political donations. The source code is publicly available. All rights reserved.

corrections.title: Corrections policy
corrections.description: We distinguish three types of corrections:
corrections.minorDesc: Typo, broken link, date update — corrected silently, tracked in Git history
corrections.substantialDesc: Change to a figure, source, or interpretation — noted in the card's 'changeSummary' field
corrections.retractionDesc: Removal of false information — explicitly flagged with explanation

verification.title: How we verify
verification.description: Every published data point goes through a verification process:
verification.doubleSource: Double source: every metric is verified by at least two independent sources, or by a single recognised institutional source (Court of Auditors, Parliament, administration)
verification.dateCheck: Date check: every source is consulted and dated. Outdated data is updated or removed.
verification.contextCheck: Context check: figures are always accompanied by their context (methodology, scope, known limitations)

protocol.title: Verification protocol
protocol.intro: A Verification is a documented editorial act whereby the BGM team assesses, on a given date, the state of an existing card against institutional sources, and makes explicit: either the absence of significant change, or the occurrence of a factual change, or the temporary inability to conclude.
protocol.v1Desc: Sources consulted confirm the situation is unchanged. Institutional silence is confirmed.
protocol.v2Desc: A new verifiable fact modifies one or more metrics or statuses. The change is documented and sourced.
protocol.v3Desc: Sources are contradictory, incomplete, or absent. No solid conclusion can be drawn. A V3 result triggers a review of the confidence level.
protocol.v4Desc: Previously published information can no longer be verified. Information is suspended until clarification. A V4 result triggers a review of the confidence level.
protocol.checklistItems: Sources reconsulted • URLs accessible or archived • Date documented • Source type identified • Result explicit (V1-V4) • No political judgment • Scope clearly limited
protocol.frequencyBudget: High-inertia domains (Budget, Legal): monthly verification or triggered by major event
protocol.frequencyOperational: Operational domains (Mobility, Social): quarterly verification or upon source publication
protocol.triggersDesc: A verification may be triggered by: (a) an A or B source contradicting a metric, (b) a documented external report, (c) a major institutional event.
protocol.nonEventsDesc: A non-event may only be documented if an expected deadline is based on a legal basis or established precedent, and the deadline breach is objectively verifiable.

parliamentPowers.title: What can Parliament do without a government?
parliamentPowers.subtitle: The actual powers of the Brussels Parliament during caretaker government

whatItCanDo.title: What Parliament can do
whatItCanDo.questions: Ask parliamentary questions to the caretaker government and demand answers
whatItCanDo.twelfths: Vote provisional twelfths to ensure budget continuity
whatItCanDo.commissions: Hold parliamentary committees and hear experts or officials
whatItCanDo.hearings: Debate resolutions and interpellations, even without full legislative capacity

whatItCannotDo.title: What Parliament cannot do
whatItCannotDo.newLaws: Vote new ordinances (regional laws) on matters requiring a fully empowered government
whatItCannotDo.budget: Adopt a real regional budget — only provisional twelfths are possible
whatItCannotDo.policy: Launch new public policies or create new programmes
whatItCannotDo.appointments: Make strategic appointments in regional bodies

twelfths.title: Provisional twelfths
twelfths.description: Voting provisional twelfths is Parliament's residual budgetary power without a government. Each quarter, Parliament authorises the Region to spend one twelfth of the last approved budget per month. This mechanism ensures administrative survival but prevents any new investment.

realWorld.title: In practice
realWorld.description: The Brussels Parliament continues to sit and work. Members ask questions, organise hearings, and debate. But their legislative capacity is structurally limited: without a government to propose and defend texts, the legislative process is largely paralysed.

concreteActivity.title: Concrete activity since June 2024
concreteActivity.description: Despite the absence of a fully empowered government, the Brussels Parliament has not been idle. Here is what it has concretely done since the elections:
concreteActivity.twelfthsVoted: Provisional twelfths votes: Parliament has voted provisional appropriations each quarter to ensure budgetary continuity for the Region, COCOM, and COCOF
concreteActivity.questions: Parliamentary questions: hundreds of written and oral questions have been addressed to the caretaker government, on subjects ranging from social housing to mobility to security
concreteActivity.hearings: Committee hearings: parliamentary committees have heard experts, heads of para-regional bodies, and field actors on the impacts of the crisis
concreteActivity.resolutions: Resolutions and interpellations: Parliament has adopted non-binding resolutions calling for accelerated negotiations and the protection of certain budgets

composition.title: Current composition
composition.description: The Brussels Parliament has 89 members divided into two linguistic groups: 72 members in the French linguistic group and 17 members in the Dutch linguistic group. The presidency is held on a rotating basis. The 89 members are spread across 13 parties, making it one of the most fragmented parliaments in Belgium.

doubleMajorityDetail.title: The double majority: key to the crisis
doubleMajorityDetail.description: To invest a Brussels government, a majority must be secured in EACH linguistic group: 37/72 on the French-speaking side AND 9/17 on the Dutch-speaking side. With 13 fragmented parties, finding a combination that works on both sides simultaneously is an arithmetic puzzle. This constitutional requirement, designed to protect the Dutch-speaking minority, is the structural mechanism that explains the exceptional duration of the current crisis.

paradox.title: The paradox of a Parliament without a government
paradox.description: Parliament is the only Brussels regional institution operating at full capacity. It sits, it debates, it scrutinises. But it is structurally limited: without a government to table and defend draft ordinances, Parliament is an engine running at half speed. It can ask questions, but it cannot legislate. It can vote provisional twelfths, but it cannot vote a real budget. It can raise the alarm, but it cannot act.

brusselsParadox.title: The Brussels paradox: rich in GDP, poor in income
brusselsParadox.subtitle: Why Belgium's economic capital lacks resources

gdp.title: 19% of Belgian GDP
gdp.description: Brussels produces approximately 19% of Belgium's gross domestic product, with only 10% of the population. This economic wealth is explained by the concentration of European institutions, corporate headquarters, and financial services. Brussels' GDP per capita is the highest in the country.

commuters.title: 360,000 commuters
commuters.description: Every day, approximately 360,000 workers commute to Brussels from Flanders and Wallonia. They contribute to Brussels' GDP but pay their income taxes in their municipality of residence. Brussels bears the infrastructure costs without benefiting from the corresponding tax revenues.

income.title: Lower disposable income
income.description: Despite a high GDP, the average disposable income per capita in Brussels is lower than in Flanders. Poverty affects 30% of the Brussels population. The regional unemployment rate (15.3%) is the highest of the three Belgian Regions.

transfers.title: Fiscal transfers
transfers.description: The Belgian tax system redistributes part of the revenue between Regions. Brussels is both a net contributor to national GDP and a beneficiary of solidarity mechanisms. The question of Brussels' funding — particularly compensation for commuters — is a recurring theme in institutional negotiations.

whyMatters.title: Why this matters for the crisis
whyMatters.description: The Brussels paradox explains why the government crisis hits so hard: a structurally underfunded Region that loses its investment capacity for two years sees its public services deteriorate faster than the other two Regions.

levelsOfPower.title: Who decides what in Brussels?
levelsOfPower.subtitle: Six levels of power impact the lives of Brussels residents. Here are their roles, their competences, and their current status.
levelsOfPower.intro: Brussels is the most institutionally complex city in Europe. Six levels of power overlap, each with its own competences. In normal times, this complexity is invisible to the citizen. In times of crisis, it becomes the problem: when one level is blocked, the others cannot always compensate.

table.euExamples: Funding (ERDF, ESF+), environmental standards, European Semester
table.federalExamples: Social security, justice, taxation, SNCB/NMBS, defence
table.regionExamples: Housing, employment, mobility, environment, regional budget
table.communitiesExamples: Health, social welfare, culture (COCOM, COCOF, VGC)
table.communesExamples: Urban planning, civil registry, CPAS/OCMW, local police, roads
table.pararegionalExamples: Actiris, STIB/MIVB, Brussels Housing, Brussels Environment

eu.title: The European Union
eu.role: The EU does not govern Brussels, but it shapes a significant part of its environment. European funds (ERDF, ESF+) finance infrastructure and social cohesion projects. European directives set binding targets for air quality, energy efficiency, and the labour market. The European Semester assesses Belgian budgetary policies, including the situation in Brussels.
eu.impact: During the 2024-2026 crisis, Brussels risked being unable to programme European funds within the required deadlines. The Dilliès government must now make up for the accumulated delay in mobilising ERDF and ESF+ funds for the 2021-2027 period.

federal.title: The federal state
federal.competences: The federal state manages social security (unemployment, pensions, healthcare), justice, the federal police, national taxation, railways (SNCB/NMBS), and defence. These competences directly impact Brussels residents: unemployment benefits, healthcare reimbursements, and the trains serving Brussels depend on the federal level, not the Region.
federal.asymmetry: The federal government (Arizona coalition) has been operational since early 2025. During the 2024-2026 crisis, it made decisions that impacted Brussels — tax reforms, refinancing of federated entities, cooperation agreements — without the Brussels Region having a fully empowered government to defend its interests in negotiations. This asymmetry was one of the most concrete consequences of the crisis. Since February 2026, the Dilliès government can once again represent Brussels at the federal level.

regions.title: The three Regions: an unprecedented asymmetry
regions.comparison: After the June 2024 elections, Flanders and Wallonia quickly formed their regional governments. Brussels took 613 days — an unprecedented asymmetry in Belgian history. For nearly two years, two of three Regions could legislate, invest, and programme their policies, while Brussels operated on minimal management. On the same matters (housing, employment, mobility, environment), Flanders and Wallonia moved forward while Brussels fell behind.
regions.consequences: Inter-regional cooperation agreements — necessary for issues such as commuter mobility or water management — were blocked on the Brussels side during the 2024-2026 crisis. Businesses active in multiple Regions faced regulatory inconsistencies. Financial transfers between Regions continued on outdated parameters, with no possibility of renegotiation. Since February 2026, these inter-regional negotiations can resume.

communities.title: The community commissions: Brussels' institutional layer cake
communities.cocom: The COCOM/GGC (Joint Community Commission) manages bi-community matters in Brussels: hospitals, nursing homes, homeless shelters, health policy coordination. Its government consists of the same ministers as the regional government. During the 2024-2026 crisis, COCOM was paralysed for the same 613 days: investments in health and social welfare were frozen. Since February 2026, it has regained its full capacity.
communities.cocofVgc: The COCOF (French Community Commission) manages French-speaking matters (culture, vocational training, personal assistance) and has its own budget and decree-making power. The VGC (Flemish Community Commission) fulfils the same role on the Dutch-speaking side but is structurally more linked to the Flemish government. Both commissions function with their own budgets and governance, distinct from the regional government.

communes.title: The 19 municipalities: crisis shock absorbers
communes.role: The 19 Brussels municipalities (City of Brussels, Ixelles, Schaerbeek, Molenbeek, Anderlecht, etc.) exercise proximity competences: urban planning, civil registry, local police, CPAS/OCMW (social welfare), municipal education, local roads. During the 2024-2026 crisis, municipalities were the main shock absorber: often the only level of power that acted concretely for citizens in daily life.
communes.disparities: But municipal resources are unequal. High-income municipalities (Uccle, Woluwe-Saint-Pierre) have solid tax revenues. Low-income municipalities (Molenbeek, Saint-Josse, Anderlecht) depend more on regional subsidies. During the crisis, these subsidies were frozen, deepening inequalities between municipalities.

provinces.title: The absence of a province: a unique exception
provinces.exception: Brussels is the only Belgian Region without a province. In Flanders and Wallonia, provinces play a significant operational role: provincial education, cultural heritage, sports infrastructure, co-funding of local projects. In Brussels, the Region directly assumes these provincial competences, under the special law of 12 January 1989.
provinces.consequence: This absence means the Brussels Region carries a broader range of competences than the other two Regions. In normal times, this is an advantage (fewer intermediaries). In times of crisis — as between 2024 and 2026 — this is a handicap: there is no 'Brussels province' to take over certain matters when the Region is paralysed.

pararegional.title: Para-regional bodies
pararegional.organisms: The regional public interest bodies form the operational administration of Brussels: Actiris (employment), STIB/MIVB (transport), Brussels Housing (housing), Brussels Environment (environment), perspective.brussels (urban planning), Innoviris (research), Bruxelles-Propreté (waste). These bodies operate under multi-year management contracts.
pararegional.limits: During the 2024-2026 crisis, 'continuing' was not 'advancing'. Management contracts expired without being renewed. New investments were blocked. Projects requiring a political decision — a new tram line, an energy renovation programme, an employment aid reform — were frozen. The new government must renegotiate these contracts and unlock the investments that were put on hold.

policeZones.title: Police zones
policeZones.description: Brussels has 6 local police zones (Brussels-Capital/Ixelles, South, West, Marlow, Montgomery, North), each managed by a police council made up of municipal representatives. The police operates independently of the regional government, but during the 2024-2026 crisis, regional security allocations were frozen at 2024 levels. Investments in equipment, recruitment, and police infrastructure were postponed.

blockage.title: Where was the blockage? (2024-2026)
blockage.description: For 613 days, the blockage was concentrated at the level of the Brussels-Capital Region and the COCOM. These two levels — which share the same government — were the only ones without a fully empowered executive. The federal level, municipalities, para-regional bodies, and police zones continued to function, but they could not compensate for the absence of a regional vision, investment budget, and legislative capacity. Since February 2026, all Brussels levels of power are once again operational.

whoDecidesWhat.title: Who decides what?
whoDecidesWhat.intro: Which level of power decides what? Here are the main competences and the responsible institution:
whoDecidesWhat.budgetWho: Brussels Parliament (on proposal from the government)

governmentFormation.title: How is a Brussels government formed?
governmentFormation.subtitle: The formation process, from election to inauguration

steps.title: The steps of the formation
steps.electionsDesc: Brussels residents elect the 89 members of the regional Parliament (72 French-speaking + 17 Dutch-speaking)
steps.consultationDesc: The President of Parliament consults the parties and may designate an informateur to explore possible coalitions
steps.formationDesc: A formateur is designated to negotiate a government agreement between the parties of the future coalition
steps.agreementDesc: The parties sign a government agreement setting out the programme and the composition of the government
steps.governmentDesc: The government is constituted and takes the oath before Parliament

doubleMajority.title: The double linguistic majority
doubleMajority.description: The Brussels particularity is the requirement for majorities in both linguistic groups of Parliament. The government must include ministers from both groups. Certain decisions require a majority in each group. This mechanism protects the Dutch-speaking minority but considerably complicates coalition formation.

differenceFederal.title: Difference from the federal level
differenceFederal.description: At the federal level, the King plays an active role: he designates informateurs and formateurs. At the Brussels regional level, it is the President of Parliament who leads the process. There is no royal role in the formation of regional governments — it is an exclusively parliamentary competence.

elections2024.title: Results of 9 June 2024
elections2024.intro: The regional elections of 9 June 2024 produced a highly fragmented parliament. Seven French-speaking and six Dutch-speaking parties share the 89 seats. No simple coalition commands a simultaneous majority in both linguistic groups.
elections2024.source: Source: FPS Interior, official results of 9 June 2024. Figures may differ slightly depending on recounts. BGM verification: February 2026.
elections2024.arithmeticDesc: To form a government, a majority in each linguistic group is required: 37 seats out of 72 on the French-speaking side and 9 seats out of 17 on the Dutch-speaking side. On the French-speaking side, several combinations of 3-4 parties reach 37 seats. But on the Dutch-speaking side, with only 17 seats spread across 6 parties, finding 9 seats that are politically compatible with the French-speaking coalition is extremely difficult. It is this arithmetic constraint that explains the failure of the six rounds of formation.

currentCrisis.title: The current crisis
currentCrisis.description: Since the elections of 9 June 2024, six rounds of formation have taken place without resulting in a government. The main blockage is the double linguistic majority: the combinations that work on the French-speaking side do not find a corresponding majority on the Dutch-speaking side.

whyHarder.title: Why it is harder in Brussels
whyHarder.description: Unlike the federal level, forming a Brussels government combines three unique difficulties: (1) the double linguistic majority requires a simultaneous agreement in two distinct electoral blocs; (2) there is no royal role to facilitate mediation — the President of Parliament alone leads the process; (3) party fragmentation is extreme: 13 parties for 89 seats, an average of 7 seats per party. At the federal level, the King can appoint informateurs and formateurs with a moral authority that does not exist at the regional level.

brusselsOverview.title: Brussels at a glance
brusselsOverview.subtitle: Understand Brussels in 5 minutes, with no prior knowledge
brusselsOverview.intro: Brussels is a city unique in the world. Capital of Belgium, seat of the European Union, and a Region in its own right, it is governed by an institutional architecture of exceptional complexity. Here is the essential.

keyFigures.title: Brussels in 5 figures
keyFigures.gdpDesc: but a disposable income below the national average
keyFigures.languagesDesc: the most cosmopolitan city in Belgium

doubleStatus.title: A unique double status
doubleStatus.description: Brussels is the only entity in Belgium to be both a Region (like Flanders or Wallonia) and the country's capital. This dual role means Brussels manages its own regional competences (housing, employment, mobility) while hosting federal and European institutions on its territory.

complexity.title: Why 6 governments?
complexity.description: On Brussels territory, six levels of power exercise competences: the federal level, the Region, the COCOM (bi-community), the COCOF (French-speaking), the VGC (Dutch-speaking), and the 19 municipalities. This architecture is the result of historical compromises between linguistic communities. In normal times, it works. When one level is blocked — as the Region and the COCOM have been since June 2024 — the consequences cascade.

euImpact.title: Capital of Europe
euImpact.description: Brussels hosts the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Council of the EU, the NATO headquarters, and more than 4,000 international organisations. Around 120,000 international officials work there. This status generates considerable economic activity but also creates a fiscal paradox: many of these workers benefit from tax exemptions and do not fully contribute to regional revenues.

commuterParadox.title: The commuter paradox
commuterParadox.description: Every day, approximately 360,000 commuters enter Brussels to work. They contribute to 19% of national GDP but pay their taxes in their municipality of residence, in Flanders or Wallonia. Brussels produces the wealth but captures only a fraction of it. This gap between high GDP and low income is at the heart of the 'Brussels paradox'.

brusselsOverview.linkFormation: How is a Brussels government formed?
brusselsOverview.linkParadox: The Brussels paradox: GDP vs income
brusselsOverview.sources: Sources: IBSA (regional statistics), Brussels Parliament (composition), Eurostat (EU data), Statbel (population).

brusselsCosmopolitan.title: Cosmopolitan Brussels
brusselsCosmopolitan.subtitle: The international dimension and superdiversity of the capital
brusselsCosmopolitan.intro: Brussels is not just the capital of Belgium. It is one of the most international cities in the world, a crossroads where European institutions, international organisations, and a population of unique diversity in Europe converge.

euCapital.title: Capital of the European Union
euCapital.description: Brussels concentrates the main EU institutions: the European Commission (Berlaymont), the European Parliament (Leopold Quarter), the Council of the EU (Justus Lipsius/Europa). More than 30,000 European civil servants work there, alongside thousands of lobbyists, journalists, diplomats, and consultants. The European Quarter constitutes a veritable 'state within the city'.

internationalOrgs.title: Beyond the EU: a global hub
internationalOrgs.description: Brussels is also the headquarters of NATO, which employs approximately 4,000 people there. More than 4,000 NGOs, professional federations, and international organisations are established there. This concentration of international actors makes Brussels the second diplomatic city in the world after New York.

fiscalImpact.title: The paradoxical fiscal impact
fiscalImpact.description: Officials of European institutions and NATO benefit from a special tax regime: they pay an internal community tax but are exempt from Belgian income taxes. They consume Brussels public services (roads, transport, security) without contributing proportionally to regional revenues. This gap reinforces the Brussels paradox: a city rich in economic activity but structurally deficient in tax revenues.

superdiversity.title: Brussels superdiversity
superdiversity.description: Brussels is the most diverse city in Belgium and one of the most diverse in Europe. More than 180 nationalities coexist there and more than 100 languages are spoken daily. French is the dominant lingua franca, but Dutch, Arabic, Turkish, English, and Portuguese are among the most spoken languages at home.

dutchStatus.title: Dutch: a protected minority
dutchStatus.description: Approximately 5 to 8% of Brussels residents are native Dutch speakers, but the protection of the Dutch-speaking minority is enshrined in the Constitution through the double linguistic majority and community institutions (VGC). The Dutch linguistic group in Parliament (17 seats out of 89) holds an effective veto right on government formation — it is precisely this mechanism that is at the heart of the current crisis.

demographicChallenge.title: The demographic challenge
demographicChallenge.description: Brussels is the youngest Region in Belgium: 24% of the population is under 18 (compared to 20% in Flanders and Wallonia). The population has grown by 20% in twenty years. This growth places constant pressure on public services — schools, childcare, housing, transport — which are precisely the sectors frozen by the absence of government.

brusselsCosmopolitan.linkSocial: Social affairs: safety nets under strain
brusselsCosmopolitan.sources: Sources: IBSA, Eurostat, Neighbourhood Monitoring, Statbel, Brussels Parliament.

brusselsRegion.title: The Brussels-Capital Region
brusselsRegion.subtitle: Government, Parliament, competences and budget of the Region
brusselsRegion.intro: The Brussels-Capital Region is one of Belgium's three Regions, established by the special law of 12 January 1989. It exercises its own competences over a territory of 161 km² housing 1.2 million inhabitants and 19 municipalities.

government.title: The regional government
government.description: The Brussels government consists of a Minister-President and four ministers, of whom at least two from each language group (French-speaking and Dutch-speaking). They are assisted by three regional state secretaries. The government exercises executive power: it proposes ordinances to Parliament, manages the administration and implements regional policies.

parliament.title: The Brussels Parliament
parliament.description: The Parliament of the Brussels-Capital Region has 89 members: 72 from the French language group and 17 from the Dutch language group. It votes ordinances (regional laws), the budget and oversees the government. The double linguistic majority — required for government formation — is one of the key features of Brussels' institutional architecture.

competences.title: Regional competences
competences.description: The Region exercises competences in many areas that directly affect the daily lives of Brussels residents:
competences.list: Spatial planning and urbanism — Housing — Environment and water policy — Employment and economy — Mobility and public works — Energy — External relations and foreign trade — Scientific research — Supervision of municipalities
competences.note: The Region has also taken over provincial competences (Brussels has no province), which broadens its scope compared to the other two Regions.

budget.title: The regional budget
budget.description: The budget of the Brussels-Capital Region amounts to approximately 7 billion euros per year. It is funded by federal transfers (special financing law), own tax revenues (vehicle tax, property tax) and European funds. Brussels suffers from a structural imbalance: it produces 19% of Belgium's GDP but captures only a fraction of the corresponding tax revenues due to the commuter effect.

pararegional.title: Para-regional bodies
pararegional.description: The Region relies on a network of public interest bodies to implement its policies: Actiris (employment), STIB/MIVB (transport), Brussels Environment, Brussels Housing, perspective.brussels (urban planning), Innoviris (research), Bruxelles-Propreté (waste management). These bodies operate under multi-year management contracts.

brusselsRegion.linkCocom: See also: COCOM, which shares the same government
brusselsRegion.linkLevels: See also: the levels of power in Brussels

cocom.title: COCOM: the Common Community Commission
cocom.subtitle: The bicommunal institution managing health and social welfare in Brussels
cocom.intro: COCOM (Commission communautaire commune), or GGC in Dutch, is a unique institution in Belgium. It manages 'bi-personal' matters in Brussels — those concerning people regardless of their linguistic affiliation: health, social welfare, elderly care, disability.

whyItMatters.title: Why COCOM matters
whyItMatters.description: In Brussels, when you go to a hospital, nursing home or social welfare centre that is not affiliated with either the French or Flemish Community, it is COCOM that regulates and subsidises it. It is also COCOM — through Iriscare — that manages Brussels family allowances since the 6th State Reform.

governance.title: Governance
governance.description: The United Assembly of COCOM consists of the same 89 parliamentarians as the Brussels Parliament. Its United College consists of the same ministers as the regional government (without the state secretaries). Direct consequence: when the regional government is in caretaker mode, so is COCOM. The two institutions are structurally linked.

iriscare.title: Iriscare: the operational arm
iriscare.description: Iriscare is the bicommunal public interest body created by COCOM. It concretely manages family allowances, disability assistance, funding for nursing homes and care institutions. It is the Brussels equivalent of AVIQ (Wallonia) or VAPH (Flanders).

competences.title: Competences
competences.description: Bicommunal health policy — Assistance to persons (CPAS/OCMW, homeless, social welfare) — Family allowances — Elderly care (nursing homes) — Disability — Hospital coordination

crisisImpact.title: The 2024-2026 crisis: lessons for COCOM
crisisImpact.description: Between June 2024 and February 2026, COCOM was paralysed alongside the regional government: no new ordinances, no new health investments, no renewal of agreements with care institutions. The most urgent dossiers — mental health plan, reform of homeless assistance — were frozen for 613 days. Since the swearing-in of the Dilliès government (February 2026), COCOM has regained its full capacity for action.

cocof.title: COCOF: the French Community Commission
cocof.subtitle: The French-speaking institution of Brussels
cocof.intro: COCOF (Commission communautaire française) is one of Brussels' three community commissions. It exercises competences transferred by the French Community (Wallonia-Brussels Federation) in the areas of culture, social action, vocational training and health, for institutions and persons under the French-speaking language regime in Brussels.

governance.title: Governance
governance.description: The COCOF Assembly consists of the 72 parliamentarians from the French language group of the Brussels Parliament. Its College consists of the French-speaking members of the regional government. COCOF has its own budget and decree-making power: it can adopt decrees with the force of law in its areas of competence.

competences.title: Competences
competences.description: Social action and assistance to persons — Vocational training — Health policy (French-speaking component) — Culture — Sport — Tourism. COCOF operates for institutions affiliated with the French-speaking language regime: training centres, medical houses, cultural centres, etc.

budget.title: Budget
budget.description: COCOF's budget is approximately 600 million euros. It is funded by grants from the Region, the French Community and own revenues. COCOF is often described as the 'small French Community of Brussels': it locally exercises part of the community competences.

vgc.title: VGC: the Flemish Community Commission
vgc.subtitle: The Dutch-speaking institution of Brussels
vgc.intro: The VGC (Vlaamse Gemeenschapscommissie) is the Dutch-speaking counterpart of COCOF. It manages Flemish community matters in Brussels: culture, education, welfare, sport. The VGC plays a central role for the Dutch-speaking community in Brussels and its institutions.

governance.title: Governance
governance.description: The VGC Assembly consists of the 17 parliamentarians from the Dutch language group of the Brussels Parliament. Its College consists of the Dutch-speaking members of the regional government. Unlike COCOF, the VGC does not have decree-making power: it adopts 'verordeningen' (regulations), not decrees.

competences.title: Competences
competences.description: Dutch-speaking culture — Education — Welfare and social assistance — Sport — Reception and integration — Training. The VGC manages a network of Dutch-speaking institutions in Brussels: community centres, libraries, youth centres, etc.

flemishLink.title: Link with the Flemish Community
flemishLink.description: The VGC is structurally closer to the Flemish Government than COCOF is to the French Community government. Flanders invests heavily in its Brussels institutions through the VGC, considering Brussels as its capital. This strong link means that Dutch-speaking institutions in Brussels are often better funded per capita than French-speaking institutions.

vgc.linkCommunities: See also: the Communities in Brussels

communitiesInBrussels.title: The Communities in Brussels
communitiesInBrussels.subtitle: The Wallonia-Brussels Federation and the Flemish Community: their role in the capital
communitiesInBrussels.intro: Brussels is the only territory in Belgium where the two major linguistic Communities — the Wallonia-Brussels Federation (FWB) and the Flemish Community (Vlaamse Gemeenschap) — simultaneously exercise their competences. This coexistence lies at the heart of Brussels' institutional complexity.

fwb.title: The Wallonia-Brussels Federation (FWB)
fwb.description: The FWB — officially the 'French Community of Belgium' — exercises its competences in Brussels in education, culture, audiovisual, research and youth assistance. It manages French-speaking schools, nurseries, youth centres and cultural institutions affiliated with the French-speaking regime. Its influence in Brussels is considerable: the vast majority of Brussels institutions fall under the French-speaking regime.

vlGem.title: The Flemish Community (Vlaamse Gemeenschap)
vlGem.description: The Flemish Community exercises the same competences as the FWB, but for institutions affiliated with the Dutch-speaking regime: schools, nurseries, cultural centres, media. In Flanders, the Community and the Region have merged (there is only one Flemish Parliament and one Flemish Government). But in Brussels, the Flemish Community operates through the VGC for 'person-related' matters.

competences.title: Community competences
competences.description: Education (all levels) — Culture and audiovisual — Youth assistance — Sport — Applied scientific research — Health policy (prevention). These competences are exercised in Brussels by each Community for the institutions falling under it. For 'bi-personal' matters (those concerning people regardless of their language regime), COCOM intervenes.

whyItMatters.title: Why this matters for Brussels
whyItMatters.description: The community duality has very concrete consequences. A Brussels resident who wants to enrol their child in a school chooses between the French-speaking network (FWB) and the Dutch-speaking network (Flemish Community). Waiting lists, programmes and funding differ. In culture, two parallel networks coexist. This architecture, the fruit of historical compromises, guarantees each community's autonomy but fragments governance.

communitiesInBrussels.linkCocof: See also: COCOF (French-speaking relay in Brussels)
communitiesInBrussels.linkVgc: See also: VGC (Dutch-speaking relay in Brussels)

federalAndBrussels.title: The Federal State and Brussels
federalAndBrussels.subtitle: The presence and impact of the federal state in the capital
federalAndBrussels.intro: The federal state is omnipresent in Brussels. It exercises competences that directly affect the daily lives of Brussels residents: social security, justice, federal police, railways, taxation. Brussels is also the federal capital, which entails specific responsibilities and funding.

competences.title: Federal competences in Brussels
competences.description: Social security (unemployment, pensions, healthcare) — Justice (courts, administration, penitentiary) — Federal police — Railways (SNCB/NMBS) — National taxation (personal income tax, VAT, corporate tax) — Defence — Migration and asylum policy.

beliris.title: Beliris: the federal-Brussels link
beliris.description: The Beliris cooperation agreement, concluded between the federal state and the Region, finances major infrastructure projects in Brussels: the metro (line 3), renovation of public buildings, cultural and sports projects. Beliris represents approximately 125 million euros per year and constitutes a form of compensation for the capital role that Brussels plays.

justice.title: Justice in Brussels
justice.description: Brussels houses the Palace of Justice (the largest in Europe by surface area), the courts of appeal, the courts of first instance and the federal penitentiary administration. Justice is an exclusively federal competence. Investments in Brussels' judicial infrastructure — including the seemingly endless renovation of the Palace of Justice — depend entirely on the federal budget.

security.title: Security
security.description: In Brussels, security rests on two pillars: local police (6 police zones, funded by municipalities and the Region) and federal police (funded by the federal state). Coordination is ensured by the Region's governor. The federal state also funds the security plan for Brussels through Beliris and the federal security fund.

fiscal.title: The fiscal question
fiscal.description: The federal state collects personal income tax and redistributes part of it to the Regions through the special financing law. Brussels is disadvantaged by this mechanism: commuters (360,000 per day) pay their tax in their municipality of residence, not in Brussels. The refinancing of Brussels, negotiated during the 6th State Reform (2012-2014), partially compensated for this imbalance but remains insufficient according to regional analyses.

federalAndBrussels.linkLevels: See also: the levels of power in Brussels

whoDecidesWhatPage.title: Who decides what in Brussels?
whoDecidesWhatPage.subtitle: The competence matrix: which institution manages which domain for Brussels residents
whoDecidesWhatPage.intro: Brussels is the most institutionally complex city in Europe. For a single citizen, seven different institutions exercise competences. This page helps understand, domain by domain, which entity is responsible.

howToRead.title: How to read this matrix
howToRead.description: The primary institution is the one holding decision-making authority. Other institutions involved play a role in implementation, funding or co-management. When the primary institution is blocked, the others generally cannot compensate.

circles.title: BGM's three coverage circles
circles.circle1: Circle 1 — Proactive coverage: the Region and COCOM. These are the institutions BGM follows permanently, with systematic updates.
circles.circle2: Circle 2 — Reactive coverage: the Federal State, COCOF, VGC, FWB and the Flemish Community. BGM documents their impact on Brussels when it is significant.
circles.circle3: Circle 3 — Passive coverage: European and international institutions. BGM mentions them when they directly affect a Brussels dossier.

howToRead.intro: This guide explains how to interpret the information presented on Brussels Governance Monitor. No prior political knowledge is required.
howToRead.statusIntro: Each domain card displays a status reflecting its current state:
howToRead.statusBlockedDesc: This issue cannot move forward without a new government. A political decision is legally required and no one has the authority to take it under caretaker government.
howToRead.statusDelayedDesc: This issue has fallen behind its official schedule. Deadlines have been missed or decisions postponed.
howToRead.statusOngoingDesc: This issue is progressing normally within the current framework. Existing mechanisms are functioning without new political intervention.
howToRead.statusResolvedDesc: This issue is concluded. An official decision has been taken and the identified problem has been addressed.
howToRead.confidenceIntro: Every piece of data we publish carries a confidence level indicating where it comes from:
howToRead.confidenceOfficialDesc: The information comes from an official document (ordinance, parliamentary report, public statistics). This is the most reliable level.
howToRead.confidenceEstimatedDesc: The information is calculated by BGM from public data, using a documented methodology. The margin of error is indicated when significant.
howToRead.confidenceUnconfirmedDesc: The information comes solely from press sources and has not yet been confirmed by an official document. It may evolve.
howToRead.cardsStatus: A colour-coded status (blocked, delayed, ongoing, resolved) — see above
howToRead.cardsMetrics: Key figures — essential data with their source
howToRead.cardsAnalysis: A factual analysis — what is concretely happening, without opinion
howToRead.cardsSources: Sources — with direct links to original documents
howToRead.cardsVerification: A periodic verification — indicating when the card was last verified
howToRead.falcDesc: Some cards offer an 'In brief' summary in simplified language (B1 level). This summary does not replace the full card but provides a quick initial understanding.
howToRead.timelineDesc: The timeline traces the official events of the Brussels government formation, in order. Each event is dated and sourced.
howToRead.moreMethodology: Our full methodology explains how we verify, estimate, and correct our information.
howToRead.moreExplainers: The 'Understand' pages explore key topics in depth (levels of power, the Brussels paradox, etc.).
howToRead.moreData: The Data page allows you to download all our metrics in open format (CSV, JSON).

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.intro: Brussels Governance Monitor is committed to making its content accessible to the widest possible audience, in accordance with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, Level AA.
accessibility.conformanceText: This website is partially conformant with the WCAG 2.1 Level AA standard.
accessibility.measure1: Semantic structure: HTML5 elements (header, main, nav, article, section), consistent heading hierarchy, breadcrumbs with Schema.org markup
accessibility.measure2: Keyboard navigation: skip-to-content link, keyboard navigation in dropdown menus (arrow keys, Escape), focus trap in the search dialog
accessibility.measure3: Accessible forms: associated labels, error messages announced to screen readers (ARIA live regions), properly hidden honeypot field
accessibility.measure4: Contrast: color palette verified for a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 on all informational text
accessibility.measure5: Media and motion: respects the « prefers-reduced-motion » preference, no automatic animations
accessibility.measure6: Language: dynamic lang attribute on each page (fr/nl/en/de)
accessibility.measure7: Print: dedicated stylesheet with visible URLs
accessibility.techText: HTML5, CSS (Tailwind CSS), JavaScript (React/Next.js), ARIA, Schema.org (JSON-LD).
accessibility.limitation1: Search result excerpts are rendered as raw HTML (Pagefind) and may not be fully structured.
accessibility.limitation2: Some decorative elements (SVG icons) do not yet systematically carry the aria-hidden attribute.
accessibility.anysurferText: This website aims for WCAG 2.1 Level AA conformance, the standard on which the AnySurfer label is based. AnySurfer certification has not yet been sought.
accessibility.feedbackText: If you encounter an accessibility barrier on this website, please contact us. We are committed to responding within 15 working days.
accessibility.statementDate: This statement was established on 10 February 2026.

transparency.title: Transparency
transparency.intro: Brussels Governance Monitor is an independent civic tool. Here's how we ensure the reliability of our content.
transparency.editorialSummary: No politician names, sourced confidence levels, institutional tone. Every fact is verified and attributed.
transparency.methodologySummary: Official sources, Eurostat data, verification process, explicit confidence levels.
transparency.accessibilitySummary: WCAG 2.1 Level AA conformance. Keyboard navigation, verified contrast ratios, screen reader support.
transparency.sourceSummary: The code is publicly available. Every change is traceable.
transparency.fundingText: This project is developed and maintained by Advice That SRL (Brussels). It is currently self-funded. No advertiser, political party, or public institution contributes to the funding of this website. The project is open to public or philanthropic funding compatible with its editorial independence. Contact us if you wish to support this initiative.
transparency.correctionText: Any reported factual error is corrected within 48 hours and documented in the changelog.
